Title:
Cytospora species causing dieback on Quercus mongolica from
Mount Dongling of China
Abstract:
Mongolian oak (Quercus mongolica) is an excellent tree
species for windbreak forests, water conservation forests and fireproof
forests in China. However, it is suffering from various fungal diseases.
In this study, destructive canker diseases of Q. mongolica were
investigated in Beijing, China. They were identified as Cytospora
querceae sp. nov. and C. vinacea based on detailed morphological
comparisons and phylogeny of ITS, LSU, act, rpb2, tef1-Î± and tub2 loci.
The novel species, C. querceae, is characterized by forming scattered
and erumpent pycnidia with multiple locules, producing hyaline,
allantoid, smooth, aseptate and a little curved in the middle conidia.
This study is the first record of C. querceae and C. vinacea on Quercus
mongolica. These two species were also confirmed as causal agent of
dieback on Q. mongolica by pathogenicity tests conducted on 2-year-old
plants in greenhouse. The results obtained in this study improve the
understanding of species causing canker or dieback diseases on important
economic forest trees, and provide useful information for the effective
disease management of Q. mongolica in China.
